citation.article-title: Sedimenticola selenatireducens, gen. nov., sp. nov., an anaerobic selenate-respiring bacterium isolated from estuarine sediment

p.s: Description of Sedimenticola selenatireducens sp. nov.
Sedimenticola selenatireducens (se.le.na.ti re.du’ cens. N.L. fem. selenas selenate, L. part adj. reducens reducing; L. part. adj. selenatireducens reducing selenate).
All of the characteristics mentioned above.
Selenate reduction to selenite is coupled to 4-hydroxybenzoate utilization.
Aromatic acids such as 3-hydroxybenzoate, 4-hydroxybenzaote, benzoate, and short chain fatty acids such as acetate, pyruvate and lactate serve as substrates for growth.
In agar shake tubes, colonies are round, about 5 mm in diameter, and bright red colored due to elemental selenium formed during selenate reduction.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are hexa- and octadecanoic acid and their corresponding mono-unsaturated fatty acids (16:0, 18:0, 16:1 ω7cis and 18:1 ω7cis).
The mole G+C ratio of the DNA is 57%.
Isolate AK4OH1T, from an estuarine sediment sample of the Hudson River estuary, is the type strain (=ATCC BAA-1233T).
The GenBank accession number for the near complete 16S rRNA gene is AF432145.
